We've often referred to, I'm sure you've heard somebody refer to this passage as being the hall of faith chapter. Many would refer to those that are written here and named in this chapter as the heroes of the faith, and we see that these are individuals that were called by God to fulfill what God had for them as individuals. By faith, they obeyed the Lord, they finished, fulfilled what God had for them, and it certainly is encouraging to read this chapter and to be encouraged by what God has done in their lives, but even before you get into all of the real, maybe well-known events, I notice a statement in verse number five that just captured my attention as we were praying for our young people throughout the week, being at teen camp, and as I was preparing the message this morning and just looking even in our Sunday school class this morning with the life of Samuel and how the Bible says that Samuel judged Israel all the days of his life, and he was faithful to serve God, though he had a ministry that was taxing, no doubt, traveling from city to city and judging the people, and yet, because of his connection to God, we find that he was able to serve God all the days of his life. If you look in the passages I mentioned in Sunday school this morning, the key to that portion of scripture is that in Ramah, his hometown, he built there an altar unto the Lord, and how important worship is in our time with God. I was so just disappointed to hear the statistic that Brianna shared that the average, I'm not sure who they survey when they come up with those statistics. I wasn't called, I'm sure that many of you were not called, but it's so frightening to me to think that there would be any group of people that would claim to be followers of the Lord Jesus Christ and the average time spent in prayer to be two minutes. That's sad. There's a book that I was made aware of back in 1997, and that book was on a very prominent display in a Christian bookstore, and that book was entitled How to Pray in Nine Minutes and 59 Seconds, and I thought how horrible of a title of a book that must be that we're gonna try to squeeze God into less than 10 minutes. The reality is that now two minutes is what this statistic is, and yet the reality is that we can spend as much time with God as we want. What a privilege. I'm so thankful that God doesn't say time's up, next. We just enter into his presence, bring our petitions before his throne. I wonder this evening if someone were to summarize my life, if someone were to summarize your life with just one statement, that's all they were allowed to have, was one statement to summarize your life, I wonder what it would be. I wonder how somebody would summarize. I'm not asking how you would summarize your life. I'm asking how someone else might summarize your life. And then if we take it even a step further, we can ask ourselves this question, how would God summarize our lives? Because here God is giving us a summary statement of the life of Enoch. I believe that those three words, this testimony of Enoch, those words are insightful. They reveal to us something about Enoch's walk with God. I think this evening that what Paul, under the inspiration of the Holy Spirit of God, acknowledged to the believers in Philippi of those that were seeking their own is certainly true even in the day and age in which we live. How could we live a life that's pleasing to God? People can feel that way. Can I tell you this evening, we don't ever have to feel that way with God. You know why?
